comments.text: I was discussing Necko HTTP logs with someone today. It occurred to me that it would be really handy to have the ability to dump HTTP traffic, particularly traffic over SSL, in a format that can be consumed by Wireshark.
comments.raw_text: I was discussing Necko HTTP logs with someone today. It occurred to me that it would be really handy to have the ability to dump HTTP traffic, particularly traffic over SSL, in a format that can be consumed by Wireshark.
comments.creator: bugzilla@twinql.com
comments.author: bugzilla@twinql.com
andrew.quartey@gmail.com
comments.creator: andrew.quartey@gmail.com
comments.text: Interesting and challenging at the same time. I will read up on the relevant files and ping you on IRC, Richard. In the mean time, i will appreciate it if you can give me some links to files you think might prove useful.
comments.raw_text: Interesting and challenging at the same time. I will read up on the relevant files and ping you on IRC, Richard. In the mean time, i will appreciate it if you can give me some links to files you think might prove useful.

comments.creator: bugzilla@twinql.com
comments.author: bugzilla@twinql.com
comments.text:
Andrew: some examples of HTTP traffic are here:

http://wiki.wireshark.org/SampleCaptures#HyperText_Transport_Protocol_.28HTTP.29

and tcpdump's docs are here:

http://www.tcpdump.org/tcpdump_man.html#lbAG

The big win here would be writing HTTPS logs in the clear, of course.
comments.raw_text:
Andrew: some examples of HTTP traffic are here:

http://wiki.wireshark.org/SampleCaptures#HyperText_Transport_Protocol_.28HTTP.29

and tcpdump's docs are here:

http://www.tcpdump.org/tcpdump_man.html#lbAG

The big win here would be writing HTTPS logs in the clear, of course.

this could be a very useful feature, although I don't understand how you can have both a packet format and remove the SSL at the same time, but I would advise you to engage the security and privacy review teams before writing code.

They can help you do so, if it can be done, in an acceptable way for firefox. It really sucks to do all the development and then realize it needs major changes only after the fact. (been there.)

There might be no issue as long as it is enabled with something out of band (such as the way http logging is enabled).

good luck!

https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Reviews/ or emailing curtis koenig or sid stamm are good starting points - they're good people.

comments.raw_text: Thanks Patrick. I will keep that in mind. Anyway, i am yet to devise an approach for this. When i do, the relevant parties will be duly notified.
